Fiedman was wrong about that, JP. The depression started when a great big honking equity bubble popped (the msot public even there was black thursday, but the bubble included real estate as well). The Fed tried to fight inflation by tightening the money supply, but demand for expansion capital was FLAT. Using rates to tighten the money supply only works if it cools demand for expansion capital, thus clowing the creation of fiat money. If there is no demand for expansion capital, it does not matter where you put rates. Despite the rate rises, commerical borrowing was unchanged, which indicates that the rate increases did not have their desired effect.
 
 Unfettered captialism did not cause the depression, nor did a contraction of money supply. What caused the depression was largely the loose fiscal policies of the fed that caused the boom in the 20's. They ran a policy that led to the creation of huge amounts of capital and equity markets soaked it up, building na ever bigger bubble. 
 
 We have this problem where people fear deflation and we take extraordinary measures to combat it. In reality, deflation is kind of the ugly side of the market cycle. It is a natural phenomenon that shoudl be allowed when it comes. If we boost liquidity to combat deflation, we ultimatly end up building bigger and bigger bubbles (because markets WILL soak up the excess capital) then, when those bubbles burst, things are terrible nto becuase deflation HAS TO BE devestating, but because we have put it off and built a false economy. The problem has not gone away...the disease has not been cured...the painkiller just made us feel better for a while. 
 
 Andrew Mellon had it right:

Infinite growth is required. Now, any reasonable person can look at that and immediatly recognize that when you are dealing with a finite number of people and a finite number of resources, infinite growth is simply not possible. By trying to emulate infinite growth, though we set ourselves up for major falls. We essentially pretend our economic base grew when in fact it did not, and this invariably leads to collapse when reality finally sets in. 
 
 If you look at the foundations of that economic theory, it is easy to see how the mistake was made. Our economic theory was essentially forged by people who lived in a bigger world with a lot fewer people in it and a LOT mroe room for growth.
